column3: Info

column2: this term comes from scammers casting 'email' lures to 'fish'
column3: Don’t fall for suspicious emails or calls requesting personal details! They are phishing scams;; or fraudsters posing as legitamite services in order to obtain private information;; such as credit card passwords.

Ransomware attacks lock (and usually encrypt) the victim's data from access until they pay a ransom. In case you encounter one in the future;; back up your files so you won't have to depend on ransoms to get them back.
Installing an antivirus software can help protect you from malware. Even with one;; be cautious of suspicious files;; emails;; and websites;; as they may download malware without your knowledge.

column2: malware that tricks users into downloading software
column3: Scareware often comes in the form of menacing pop-up ads. Don't download the software they're trying to offer; it's usually a scam.

Adware is malware that bombards the user with unwanted advertisements. It's often performed to generate advertising revenue; however;; it may also decrease computer performance from resource consumption.
The Trojan Horse malware gets its name from the Ancient Greek story where a deceptive gift of a Trojan Horse with hidden forces led to the fall of the city of Troy.

column2: a hidden entrance that bypasses normal security checks
column3: Backdoors are often used to remotely access a system.
Spyware may come in the form of adware;; trojan horses;; browser cookies;; and system monitoring software.

column2: malware that changes other files/programs and self replicates
column3: Viruses tend to modify and/or corrupt files on a system.
Worms can self-replicate and spread on their own;; allowing for infections to quickly spread through a network.
Bots are also known as zombies. They have been compromised by someone and remotely perform malicious tasks.
Botnets are often used to perform distributed denial of service attacks.
In 2013;; a breach on Yahoo! compromised the private data;; including passwords and security question answers;; of over a billion user accounts.

column2: a tracker that logs each key that a user enters
column3: Keyloggers are legal programs. However;; they are often employed to steal confidential information that a user enters on their computer.

column2: software that protects against and removes malware
column3: Installing an antimalware software is recommended in order to protect your computer from a variety of common cyber threats.
A man-in-the-middle attack is an attack where an eavesdropper inserts him/herself between the communication of two parties;; possibly altering the messages sent and received;; for malicious purposes.

Potentially unwanted programs are usually unwanted. They're labelled differently from malware for legal reasons as they dupe the user into permitting their installation (unlike malware) through fine print;; tricky wording;; etc.
Denial-of-Service attackers seek to disrupt website or machine services by flooding the server with requests to the point where the system crashes.
A DDoS attack involves using a large number of machines;; often with hosts infected with malware;; to perform a DoS attack. It's harder to stop the attack as requests come from different sources.

column2: an attack that targets computer networks and/or devices
column3: Cyberattacks are costly. For example;; in the healthcare sector;; data breaches may cost an average of $429 per record.

column2: inserting malicious SQL code in a user input field
column3: Without errortrapping;; the use of user inputs in SQL database statements can return unauthorized sensitive information from said database.

column2: using offensive action to derail attacks
column3: Active defence is offensive action used to derail ongoing attacks. It's used to not only slow down and limit an attacker's scope of damage;; but also to collect intelligence on his/her motives and strategies.

column2: side-channel attack using a cold boot
column3: A cold boot attack performs a memory dump after cold-booting the machine; an analysis of the dumped data is then performed to find sensitive information.

column2: using a list of possibilities to guess passwords
column3: Avoid dictionary phrases in your passwords; this makes them more prone to cracking via dictionary attack.

column2: the exploitation of leaked information from a system
column3: Side-channel attacks focus on exploiting available information as opposed to finding holes in an algorithm. Such information may include power consumption.

column2: manipulating someone to obtain confidential information
column3: Social engineering uses manipulation against people;; rather than holes in a system. Don't fall for these scams!

column2: malware that hides itself and its activity
column3: Primary uses of rootkits are to hide information about itself;; its activity;; and perhaps activity of other malware.

column2: obtaining a password through constant guessing
column3: Protect your passwords from cracking! Choose strong passwords and add a lockout threshold (the account is locked out for a set duration of time after a series of failed attempts).
In cross-site scripting;; potentially malicious client-side scripts are injected into webpages for the use of other users.
Be careful of what gets downloaded! Drive-by downloads are malicious downloads that are unauthorized or performed by the user without the knowledge of the consequences.

column2: exploiting a software vulnerability before it is fixed
column3: Keep your software updated! When developers discover a vulnerability;; attackers may perform a zero-day exploit targeting the hole before it is patched. Even so;; users who have not applied the fix are vulnerable to the attack.

column2: an attack that uses DNS as a backchannel
column3: DNS tunnelling attacks a DNS server and uses it as a private communication channel and to store stolen data via queries and responses.

column2: used for event tracking on a computer
column3: Turning on auditing helps to detect security issues on the system
A strong password prevents other people/bots from guessing it and gaining access to your information! Use mixed-case letters;; symbols;; and numbers and avoid dictionary words.

column2: an account with unrestricted access to the computer/domain
column3: On Windows and other operating systems;; the built in administrator account cannot be locked out. Thus;; it is prone to brute-force attacks;; allowing for unauthorized access. To prevent this;; you can disable it.
On Windows and other operating systems;; the default Guest account does not require a password. Thus;; to prevent unauthorized access to your computer or network;; you can disable it.

column2: someone who uses a computer or a service
column3: You are a user.
The superuser is the most privileged account on a system and has no restriction to the (system-wide) changes it can make.
If the user is permitted to;; sudo allows a computer/network user to run commands and programs with the highest security privileges
User groups are used to simplify system access control; users of a similar purpose would fall in the same group and thus could have similar permissions.
Digital signatures help to ensure message integrity. Messages are signed with the sender's private key and authenticated with their public key.
Firewalls block unauthorized connections to your computer based on security rules. Unless you know what you're doing;; it's highly recommended to have one enabled.

column2: used to identify devices on a network
column3: The role of the IP address can be summed up as: 'A name indicates what we seek. An address indicates where it is. A route indicates how to get there.' - J. Postel for DARPA;; 1981
UDP is an Internet protocol (for sending packets over the Internet).
TCP/IP is an Internet protocol (for sending packets over the Internet).
Some features of different operating systems include single- or multi-tasking (ability to run several tasks at once) and single- or multi-user (ability for multiple users to logon at once).
Keep your programs and systems updated; patches fix vulnerabilites which attacks may try to take advantage of.
Scans can help you detect malware;; corrupted files;; and more.

column2: data protection on a certain device
column3: Disk encryption encrypts the entire disk drive to prevent access from unauthorized figures.
sudo allows an authorized user to run commands under (usually) superuser privileges.
The Secure Shell network protocol enables secure communications and file transfers over insecure networks.

column2: _ no. 80 is most commonly assigned to HTTP
column3: Ports are communication endpoints.
File sharing is the ability or process to share;; send;; or link files accross networks and systems.
Virtual private networks are private networks from public Internet connections. They are often used for privacy as they mask your IP address.
Trackers are prevalent on the Internet today;; used to help customize your web experience;; to collect your data into a profile;; etc.

column2: a small packet of data sent by a website to your browser
column3: Websites send cookies to a web browser to host data about a user's activity on a website;; these messages are then sent back to the website. Cookies are useful for storing user preferences as well as for tracking a user's web activity.

column2: a list of commands to be executed
column3: Scripts are useful for automating mundane tasks.
Fingerprinters are used to identify users and their browsing activity.
HTTPS is a extension of HTTP;; establishing a secure communication protocol using TLS (Transport Layer Security) or SSL (Secure Sockets Layer).
An Internet service provider is an organization that provides Internet services. They may be publicly;; privately;; commercially;; community;; nonprofit;; or government owned.
File integrity refers to whether a file has went through unauthorized changes.
Encryption protects data from unauthorized people.
A cipher is an encryption/decryption algorithm.
A key is a value used in cryptography to determine the output of an encryption or decryption.
A symmetric key is a key used for both encryption and decryption.
A public key is a key that may be made known. It's used in asymmetric cryptography.
A private key is a confidential key used to  may be made known. It's used in asymmetric cryptography.
Public key encryption help to ensure message integrity. Messages are signed with the recipient's public key and decrypted with the matching private key.
Decryption is the process of decoding ciphertext into plaintext.
Data scraping is performed by a program. Variants include screen scraping;; web scraping;; and report mining.
Biometrics authentication can be used for identification.
Cryptojacking is the act of illicitly mining cryptocurrency with another computer's CPU.
A user profile hosts one's digital identity. Sometimes;; the user profile that a website creates may be distributed as data to other companies.
The World Wide Web is a portion of the Internet that hosts resources under uniform resource locator (URL) references.
Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies encrypted by cryptography.
Ciphertext is encrypted information.

column2: a number generated from a string
column3: Hashes are used to ensure message integrity. For instance;; Alice may append to the end of her message its hash. Bob can calculate the hash of the message he receives and check if the two match.
The settings on a computer and software provide a lot of customization from security to sheer personalization.
A server is a program used for network resource management.
Plaintextis unencrypted information.
A database is a collection of data stored on a computer system.
Privilege escalation is the exploitation of a bug in order to gain elevated access to something that would otherwise be unauthorized.
Spoofing is very similar to phishing; however;; phishing results in information theft;; while spoofing may not.
Data tampering is the unauthorized modification of data;; including edits and corruption.

column2: an attack that uses a keylogger
column3: The evil maid attack uses a keylogger;; unbeknownst to the user;; to gather passwords. Physical access to the device is required so as to install the keylogger and collect the data.
Cryptography is the study and practice of secure communication measures.
Two-factor authentication requires both a password and a physical device to authenticate a user.
A sandbox is an isolated staging grounds. Code can be tested without fear of exposing vulnerabilities.
Sniffers are intended to be used to restore passwords - but they can also be used for malicious activity.
The Internet is a global network of networks;; including both private and public ones. It transports information and services of all sorts.

column2: a part of the Internet that consists of hidden networks
column3: Darknets must be accessed via anonymizing browsers. However;; as a result;; they are often used for illegal markets ('darknet markets');; espionage;; cyber warfare;; and communication.

column2: the world wide web of darknets
column3: The anonymity of the dark web users allows for both legal and illegal services - including darknet markets (e.g. drug and fraud businesses) - to flourish.

column2: web search engines can't reach here
column3: The deep web is not the same as the dark web - while;; for instance;; the deep web contains private records and data;; the dark web is widely seen as a hub for illegal activity.

column2: a part of a website URL
column3: A domain name points to an IP address; examples include google.ca and duckduckgo.com.
Onion routing anonymously transmits packets over a network through a series of encryption and decryption processes among routers in a path.

column2: precomputed tables of hash to plaintext values
column3: Rainbow tables are used to crack passwords by matching the encryption's hash value.
Packet switched networks transport network packets;; each carrying a certain number of bytes.
The DNS is a decentralized naming system; it hosts a reference of domain names to IP addresses.
localhost is the hostname used to access the host computer's network services.

Checksums are the hash values generated from a file or similar block of data. Downloaded a file from online? If the provider specified a checksum for it;; you can compare it with your download's checksum;; and if they match;; then rest assured that the files are identical.
